item.title: Is the European Border and Coast Guard a completely new entity or just a revamped version of Frontex?
item.description:
Herbert Rosenfeldt, Research Assistant and PhD candidate, University of Passau Introduction Celebrating the new European Border and Coast Guard Agency, also known as Frontex, at the Bulgarian external border with Turkey might seem like an odd festivity. However, last Thursday, high-ranking EU and Member State officials gathered at Bulgaria’s Kapitan Andreevo Border Checkpoint for this inauguration. This event marked the implementation of the European Border and Coast Guard Regulation, a significant step towards strengthening external border control in the wake of recent migration challenges...

item.title: Gigabit WiFi For Video Streaming
item.description:
WiFi has become the standard wireless connection due to its widespread availability, outpacing technologies like Bluetooth and WiMax. While cellular data is useful in the absence of WiFi, its limited bandwidth and potential for overage charges make it a secondary choice. In fact, data shows that most tablet users don’t even utilize their device’s cellular capabilities. WiFi’s strength is evident in its ability to not only replace cellular broadband but also wired connections...

item.title: I Know Where You Took Your Pictures Last Summer
item.description:
Eye-Fi, the WiFi-enabled memory card, has introduced a new feature: location tagging. Their latest product, Eye-Fi Explore, automatically adds geotags to photos as you take them. You might be surprised to learn that they haven’t actually included a GPS receiver in the small SD card. Instead, it uses a system that determines location based on known WiFi hotspots. This method covers a significant portion of the U.S. population and major metropolitan areas in Europe...

item.title: Ghost Routers In The Sky
item.description:
Wireless internet access on airplanes is becoming a reality. Although it had a slow start, major airlines like American, Delta, Northwest, and Virgin are now embracing in-flight Wi-Fi. This shift is inevitable in a society increasingly reliant on technology. We might be giving up old habits, but staying connected online is non-negotiable. Just like hotels and restaurants adapted to this need, airlines are following suit. Passengers are willing to endure cramped conditions and forgo traditional amenities, but internet access is a must-have...

item.title: Urgent Information Needed on 'Hotspots' for Asylum Applications
item.description:
Frances Webber, a lawyer, journalist, and lecturer, holds significant roles as the vice chair of the Institute of Race Relations and as co-editor for prominent legal publications. She is also the author of “Borderline Justice: the fight for refugee and migrant rights”. The European Union (EU) aims to control refugee flows through its new system for relocating refugees from Italy and Greece. This system includes a strict screening process at entry points, seemingly designed to separate a small number of “deserving” refugees from those deemed “undeserving” economic migrants, who the EU seeks to deport quickly...
